thread.section_title: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
thread.title: Assessing seabird communities

title: Assessing seabird communities
text:
Antarctic albatross displays shift in breeding habits April 30, 2012 
A new study of the wandering albatross -- one of the largest birds on Earth -- has shown that some of the birds are breeding earlier in the season compared with 30 years ago. Using the unique spectral signature of guano to identify unknown seabird colonies December 12, 2014 
Scientists have discovered that penguin and seabird poo (guano) from colonies around the Antarctic Peninsula has a unique spectral signature that can be identified from satellite imagery. The results are published this week ... Age doesn't matter for foraging albatrosses February 17, 2015 
A new study of the wandering albatrosses breeding on the sub-antarctic island of Bird Island (off South Georgia) reveals that age doesn't matter when foraging. The research, published in the journal PLOS ONE last month, shows ... Petrels tracked across the Oceans May 26, 2015 
Staff at British Antarctic Survey (BAS) are following the journeys of White-chinned Petrel fledglings as they make their first journeys over the South Atlantic Ocean in search of food. The birds have been fitted with small ... Worsening wind forecasts signal stormy times ahead for seabirds August 18, 2015 
Stronger winds forecast as a result of climate change could impact on populations of wild animals, by affecting how well they can feed, a study of seabirds suggests. Bird tracking aids seabird research August 19, 2015 
A two year study of shags on the Isle of May National Nature Reserve in Scotland reveals that when winds are strong, female birds take much longer to find food compared with males. Recommended for you October 8, 2015 
Siphonophores, they're called: Marine animals that navigate inner space like undersea mini-versions of the starship Enterprise. How to manipulate the brain to control maternal behavior in females and reduce aggression in males October 7, 2015 
Most female mammals give birth and care for their offspring, while the males often breed with multiple partners and play little role in parenting once the mating is over. Yet researchers have had a hard time pinpointing where, ... Rock-wallaby interbreeding causes rethink on evolution October 7, 2015 
Scientists have discovered that rock-wallabies living in north east Queensland are sharing genetic material despite belonging to six different species. Research points to possible fungal control for leaf-cutter ants October 7, 2015 
A 15-year study of leaf-cutter ants and their relatives across North and South America found that their nests are susceptible to infection by a diverse group of specialized fungal parasites. The discovery by biologists from ... A village of bacteria to help frogs fight disease October 7, 2015 
The naturally occurring bacteria on a frog's skin could be the most important tool for helping the animal fight off a deadly skin disease, according to an experiment conducted by Virginia Tech researchers. Young male chimpanzees play more with objects, but do not become better tool users October 7, 2015 
New research shows a difference between the sexes in immature chimpanzees when it comes to preparing for adulthood by practising object manipulationâ€”considered 'preparation' for tool use in later life.
